text:
My brother inspired
the reason to be here.

He was born with a
genetic disorder called
Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

The foundation I
started is called

Terry's Foundation
for Muscular Dystrophy
and named after my brother.

And that's how I
met Dr. Lou Kunkel,

a world-renowned geneticist
who discovered the dystrophin

gene back in 1986,
the gene that's
responsible for the disease.

In addition to
Terry's Foundation,

I started a company
called Myos, who

is working with the
Kunkel Lab on developing
a new approach to cell therapy.

Boiling it down, it
really comes to the point

of how do you get healthy muscle
cells when you inject them

into the body to go to the
muscle sites that you want,

and then to fuse to the
healthy muscle there?

And that's what we're working
on in the Kunkel Lab and Myos.

But what there is
a deep need for

is there's a deep need for
a champion of a project

to see it through
from the beginning

and as far into clinical
trial and commercialization
as you can get.

The Blavatnik Fellowship
is key because it's really

the crucial segue to allow you
to work on the project now.

What we're seeing
is that the research

is reaching a point where it's
almost to commercialization,

almost to that sweet
spot of needing

to be licensed from the
institution into a startup.

The difference that
we can make now

in continuing to drive it
forward while still in academia

can shorten the
development timeline

and bring us to a point
where we can get it

into the hands of
patients much faster.
And so now's the time.

Not two years from now,
not three years from now.
Now.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
